Since science is all behind this, you can numerically and scientifically explain how you broke the glass by using a microphone and an audio analyzing software. Go to quiet place wherein no external noise like high and low pitches or whatever sound would likely interfere what you are to record. Place the microphone inside the glass (by not touching the walls with your mic) and use a recording software like windows media player etc. to record it's sound while you hit or tap the wall of the wine glass ( in a gently manner with a hard object). You will hear a tone. Get an audio spectrum analyzer software to open your recorded sound and analyze the highest frequency (in Hertzian wave unit or simply in Hz) that appears on your recorded sound and that's it. That's the frequency you need to produce to break a wine glass.

Here comes your part to break it without severe exhaustion. Record your voice just what you did on your this video and analyze it with an audio spectrum analyzer to see where in the spectrum you sound (in terms of frequency) most and adjust your voice to the exact resonant frequency of the glass you acquired. When glass is made the cooling process and different thickness of glass from stem to bowl causes a preload tension. This tension is like a compressed spring frozen just before point braking so you don’t need to ad much energy to tip it over the threshold to crack it.

You can design a glass with higher preloading will make a glass that is easier to brake.

If you modify the ratio of rim to bowl of the glass in manufacturing and control the cooling process you should be able to make a super sensitive glass for braking.

That's actually why fiberglass is so strong. They make glass fibers which are absolutely perfect and then immediately coat them to prevent them getting any damage whatsoever. Then when they encase the woven fibres in a polymer matrix it strengthens it, particularly under tension (but also somewhat under compression- the fibers are super strong under compression, provided they don't buckle, and the matrix stops that.) But a wine glass that has never, ever been touched should be as strong. Another aspect that makes it so it's hard to break a glass using sound, is that the resonance frequency of the glass is ever so slightly dependent on the amplitude with which it is vibrating. So in order to get maximum resonance you have to adjust your pitch while the glass is resonating. But if you then deviate from the correct frequency for a little bit, the amplitude diminishes, which changes the resonance frequency enough that you're now completely off and the glass stops resonating  completely. I suspect this is why sweeps work. In a well-timed sweep you will not only hit the right frequency, but you will adjust the frequency at the right rate.

Another factor that makes glass fail after you have sung at it for a long while is moisture in your breath.  New glass is very dry.  Water molecules, from your breath, settle into those microscopic flaws, as they grow, weakening them, right where the glass is parting. The glass would rather bond on to water than onto glass on the other side of the crack.  People who cut glass, know that it is a lot easier to break a scored pane if you wet the newly made line, first.

There's an inaccuracy in this video: maximum resonance is reached when the driving frequency is very slightly lower than the resonant frequency. The reason is that driving resonance at a slightly lower frequency than that of maximum allows the resonator (the wine glass) to "keep up" with the driving frequency, no matter what the phase.

You could test wether microcracks or -hitting the right note-, is the reason why the glass breaks

For that you can do a few things:

you could change the MIT experiment a little bit, wich means
to use loudspeakers and hit the right note but have them at a volume so that the glas doesnt break immediatly.
To get to that volume you start at some point at wich you are sure the glas doesnt break but alo you need the exact frequency. then u wait for some time, lets say 30-120 minutes
if the glas does not break even after a long time, increase the volume a little bit and wait again, until it breaks or until after a long time nothing happens.. and repeat..
if the glas breaks after a long time at the same volume, it is probably the microcracks. In any case you would have to repeat the experiment multiple times

to verify your results you could examine the wine glasses with an electron microscope before and after they are treated with the soundwaves.(oh and find one where a wine glass fits in.. wich may be a bigger problem)
You would have to look for lattice defects in the untreated glass and examine the same defects, if possible, after the treatment and after breaking,
or map the number and size of the cracks in the glas if it is to difficult to find the same defects .
if the cracks increase in size and even interconnect (decreasing number of cracks) in the course of the sound treatment
you can not mark the defects somehow, because it could give you a false positive.

also you could redo the breaking with your voice, or use the recordings of you performing that if that is exact enough
and analyze your voice, to see wich volume and frequency you had when the glass broke.
